texts.textentryhtml: Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund

These are just two of the thousands of pictures of Maude Callen that Smith took for his “Nurse Midwife” photo-essay, which appeared in Life magazine’s December 3, 1951, issue. During his two-month assignment, Smith followed Callen as she tirelessly cared for the poor and predominantly black community of Pineville, South Carolina. An Episcopalian missionary, Callen trained to be a registered nurse at Tuskegee University and the Georgia Infirmary before settling in Pineville, where she worked not only as a midwife and teacher but also, in the words of the text, as a “‘doctor,’ dietician, psychologist, bail-goer, and friend.”  The essay’s opening sequence documented seventeen-year-old Alice Cooper’s labor and delivery of her child. In this unpublished lamplit scene, Maude (on the left) assists another midwife in administering an enema to the expectant mother. The other photograph, which appeared in a subsequent issue, shows Maude distributing clothes to a family whose home had been destroyed in a fire. The lengthy caption alludes to the many donations Maude received from Life readers in response to the 1951 photo-essay; cash contributions enabled her to build a clinic.
texts.remarks: States of Health (group chat for 2019-112 and 2019-110)
